STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 12, 2023
Crystal Michelle Wilson
Ennis Center for Children- Detroit
20100 Greenfield Rd,
Detroit, MI, 48235-1803
Re: License #: CB820201107
Dear Ms. Wilson:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
5/10/2023. An exit conference was held with you on 5/12/2023. Due to the violations of
applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at .
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201107
Licensee Group Organization: Ennis Center for Children Inc
Licensee Designee: Robert E Ennis
Chief Administrator: Crystal Michelle Wilson
Name of Agency: ENNIS CENTER FOR CHILDREN -
DETROIT
Agency Address: 20100 GREENFIELD RD
DETROIT, MI 48235-1803
Agency Telephone #: 3133422699
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1991
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 5/2/2023-5/10/2023
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed

in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 1 1

parental home, relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 24 3

since the last inspection N/A N/A

Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names shall not be included in
the report.
Two of five special evaluations reviewed did not show consistent documentation of
all persons interviewed and by which interviewer.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of 22 updated services plans reviewed was two days late.
2

CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
One of five adoptive family evaluations reviewed showed the evaluation was
completed on 12/24/2022, which was more than 90 days after the adoptive family's
2/9/2022 application date.
FOM 722-8 D Treatment plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed (related to 22 service plans
reviewed) did not show compliance:
• One child’s 7/10/2022-10/7/2022 treatment plan showed the caregiver did not
sign it until 12/13/2022. This child’s 1/6/2023-4/5/2023 treatment plan did not
show documentation of the birth parent’s signature.
• A second child’s 8/26/2022-11/21/2022 treatment plan did not show
documentation of the birth father’s signature.
• A third child’s 11/23/2022-2/20/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the
caregiver until 4/27/2023. The treatment plan for the birth father showed it
was mailed, but it was not dated, and I could not discern if it was provided
timely.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022; Interim 2021, cited under 722-08C.
FOM-801-3 Medical passport.
3

All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s record showed documentation of a 6/27/2022 medical passport
that did not include health information; and did not include the child’s
documented 6/13/2022 dental exam. Nor did this child’s record show
documentation of a September 2022 updated medical passport.
• A second child’s record showed documentation of 8/2/2022 medical passport
that did not include the child’s documented 7/15/2022 medical exam. Nor did
this child’s record show documentation of a November 2022 updated medical
passport, which would reflect a 9/8/2022 documented dental exam for the
child, and the prior reported 7/15/2022 medical exam.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of August 2022 updated
medical passport reflecting the child’s documented 6/20/2022 medical exam.
Additionally, this child’s record did not show documentation of a medical
passport after 5/9/2022 until 1/13/2023.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022; Interim 2021.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment.
Child Adoption Assessment Timeframes:
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.
One of eight child adoption assessments reviewed was due by 7/21/2022 and
completed 19 days late on 7/30/2022.
ADM 980 Closing documentation.
Adoption Closing Summary
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14
calendar days of the adoption finalization date to the foster
care worker and the Department of Health and Services
(DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of service cases for
inclusion in the child’s permanent record.
Three of four finalized child adoption records reviewed showed the respective child's
closing summary (DHS-222) was completed more than 14 days after the child's
adoption finalization date.
4

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12324(2)(b) Reevaluation:
• The agency was apprised the foster home reevaluation shall consistently
document the worker's assessment of the foster parent's weaknesses, as well
as their strengths.
FOM 7228 D Treatment plan:
• The agency was apprised the staff shall not mail or date a treatment plan for a
date prior to the supervisor's approval of the report.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
FOM 722-8D Treatment plan:
• The agency was advised including the date on the treatment plan that a birth
parent or caregiver refused to sign the treatment plan, and that the treatment
plan was mailed, may aid it in showing compliance to the policy.
EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
This incident related to an allegation that the foster parent slapped their adoptive
daughter in the face. During the special evaluation, the foster parent admitted to
hitting the youth. The foster home was found in violation of the foster home’s
behavor management rule. A corrective action plan was developed with the foster
family that included the foster parents reframing using physical punishment, and
completing training on behavior management, and the managment of a children
with a mood disorder.
The agency abided by all timeframes and standards pertaining to this special
evaluation except R400.12327(5)(d) for which they received a rule citation.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. This corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2022 Renewal
inspection where the agency received the following rule and policy violations:
• MCL 722.120(3) Investigation, Inspection, and examination of conditions,
book, records, reports…
• R400.12202(1)(d) Policy and procedures.
5

• R400.12212(3)(a) Personnel records.
• R400.12326(1)(c)-(d) Borrowed home.
• R400.1236(1) (f)(g) Borrowed home.
• R400.1237(1)(c) Special evaluation.
• R400.1237 (5)(d) Special evaluation.
• R400.12405(5)(a)-(b) Change of placement.
• R400.12419 (1)(c) Initial service plans.
• R400.12420 (1)(g) Updated service plans.
• R400.12421(b) Visitation and parenting time.
• R400.12604(1)(a)-(e) Orientation and application.
• R400.12605(2) Adoptive evaluation.
• R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
• ADM 300 Child adoption assessment addendum.
• ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-6H Documentation of contacts.
• FOM 722-08 Case Services Plans-Overview, Types, and Timeframes-
Supervisory Approval.
• FOM 722-08 Treatment Plans- Agreement and signature.
• FOM 722-8 E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
The agency reduced it number of rule violations this inspection; and made
significant progress on the correction action plan. The agency provided
documentations showing proofs of all the indicated training reported in the
corrective action plan. The agency also provided proofs and or examples of
various action steps and monitoring that were to occur, such as outlook monitoring
of annual ICHAT due dates and performance evaluations, as well as email
reminders to supervisors of upcoming performance evaluations; foster care
supervisor/worker supervisions; and submission of those notes to the program
director monthly for retention in the program director’s binder; email reminder of
upcoming service plans and medical due dates; spreadsheets, checklists; and
folders containing proofs of action summaries. Various other corrective action
plan proofs were shown via the record inspection, which illustrated improvements.
The agency admitted that items such as, the supervisor and director pulling and
reviewing all special evaluation for their thoroughness; and the program director
randomly auditing special evaluation reports monthly did not occur, as they had
hoped. They are continuing to work on all the items in the corrective action plan
which was developed under the prior chief administrator.
Notwithstanding the progress the agency made on this corrective plan, all aspects
were not totally successful. The agency received a few repeat violations as
indicated in this inspection report.
Chief Administrator Assessment
6

A chief administrator's annual report was submitted to me dated 4/30/2023. No
areas of concerns were noted.
Financial Overview
The agency provided an annual budget for foster care and adoption, and an
annual independent financial audit. No concerns were observed.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The interviews with staff were all basically positive. Areas of limitations reported
by staff centered on improving communication related to services and when
changes occur; and establishing more targeted resources for birth parents.
The agency does not have an independent living program, so youth interviews
were not required.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the facility was conducted, and no areas of concern were observed.
VI. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three safety alerts.
Safety Alert # 1
Concern:
The Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Analyst scheduled a home visit with
the foster parent for 4/04/2023. The home visit did not occur due issues with the
foster parent. The DCWL Analyst attempted to reschedule the home visit, but the
foster parent did not follow back up with the DCWL Analyst. The DCWL Analyst
advised the agency of the lack of contact with the foster parent, and the agency’s
needs to verify the safety of the home.
Resolution:
The agency reported there are no children placed in the foster home, and the home
had been on hold status since 7/12/2022. Notwithstanding, the agency made an
unannounced home visit to the foster home on 4/6/2023. During that home visit
multiple concerns and safety issues were observed. Those included lots of clutter, a
mattress and box spring blocking a window, a detached/nonfunctional smoke
detector; a microwave in the middle of the living room floor; garbage in the kitchen;
a dog cowering in a corner in the kitchen with an empty bowl; a crib mattress
standing against the kitchen table with a large slash in the mattress; no physical crib
was observed. On the second level in the home, the bathroom toilet was not
working, cigarette butts were in the toilet; there was a smoke detector located in the
hallway which was observed and tested to be in proper working order. No guns
were reported to be in the home; no home phone was observed. There was running
water in the sink, tub, and shower, but the toilet did not flush with the handle. The
agency provided photos of the home’s many maintenance issues. The
7

agency initiated a special evaluation on this foster home on 4/6/2023.
Safety Alert # 2
Concern:
The DCWL Analyst made a number of attempts to schedule a home visit with the foster
parent between 2/13/2023 and 3/1/2023 without success. Agency assistance was
obtained. The agency reported on 3/1/2023, the foster parent would follow up with the
DCWL Analyst. As of 3/14/2023 the foster parent had not returned the DCWL Analyst
contacts, efforts to verify the safety of the foster home.
Resolution:
The agency reported it had experienced difficulty contacting the foster parent for the
renewal inspection as of 2/26/2023. The agency made an unannounced foster home
visit on 3/1/2023; and had direct contact with the foster parent on 3/2/2023. The foster
parent apologized, advised of personal issues and a wish to not renew her license. The
foster home license was voluntarily closed on 3/9/2023.
Safety Alert # 3
Concern
The unlicense relative caregiver did not have operable smoke detectors on each level of
occupancy of the home and/or near all sleeping areas. Nor an operable carbon
monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution:
The Foster Care Supervisor make a home visit to the home. A safety plan was put in
placed regarding the smoke/carbon monixode detector. The agency provided photos
showing an installed operatable smoke/carbon monixode detector.
Concern:
All bedrooms were not observed due to the relative not allowing access to the room of
her adult son.
Resolution:
The Foster Care Supervisor make a home visit to the home. This supervisor viewed the
adult son’s bedroom. There were no safety concerns noted with the bedroom and the
lock will be removed. No firearms, medications, and any hazardous items were found.
The agency provided photos showing this room.
Concern:
The ceiling in the hallway on the second floor was being held together with a piece of
ply wood. This was also the celiing for the bedroom of the child placed in the home.
Resources were indicated as needed to ensure that repairs were completed properly for
the safety of the child placed in the home.
8

Resolution:
The relative caregiver was able to have a contractor come out to the home to make the
repairs. The agency provided pictures of the completed repairs.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
June 9, 2023
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 13, 2023
________________________________________
Linda D Tansil Date
Area Manager
9
